Technically fungi are more closely related to animals than plants, because they are both heterotrophs and fungi do not photosynthesize, and cellular respirate more (plants do cellular respirate, but take in more CO2 than they output) like animals. They also digest, even if it is outside of their body unlike animals.
Catus is the specific epithet and the species is the genus + specific epithet

Each generation is more mutated than the last. We are heading in the opposite direction of evolution. Study Genetic Entropy. You are being duped in a myth. Evolution is the biggest lie on the planet. All things reproduce after their own kind. And the ability to adapt is based on pre-existing genetics. Natural Selection is the physical mechanical barrier against evolution, it removes the too mutated and conserves the original genetic code, i.e. it is a creationist argument. All evolutionary evidence is hanging on opinions of evolutionary scientists, not science. They use "apparent evidence," which is the same type of evidence that flat earther's use. It means how something appears to be. You are being lied to.

Abdulkarim Elnaas That has nothing to do with it the thing what would happen if humans went extinct.  The Earth would mostly go on without US.  But, if honey bees went extinct the entire ecosystem would be nearly destroyed.  Humans are important to humans not the planet.  Honey Bees are important to the planet and us.  Humans are opportunist natural takers and scavengers.  Honey bees give more to the environment than they take.  We would starve and so would most other creatures if honey bees go extinct.  Only a few domesticated animals would strarve if humans went extinct.

Abdulkarim Elnaas Actually he Earth has given us as mercy as can be found in nature.  Since the emergence of man the world's climate has been as mild as it has ever been.  Humans have been genetically altering species for over 2000 years.  We modified dogs and the result they live shorter and have more medical problems.  We have modified corn/maize so it can't live without us and is mostly starch with little nutrients. Over 70% of human raised plants and 90% wild plants need honey bees.  Without pollination the vast majority of plants can't procreate.  Chimps don't relentlessly take.  They take for their need and leave the rest.  Chimps are highly social animals.  The struggle itself is mercy it taught us how take care of ourselves.  Give a man food feed him today teach a man forage for food feed him for life.  As, for human extinction many diseases could do it without harming other species.  Like small pox, polio, German measles,  and others.  Small pox is mutated form of cow pox which cows  are immune but because of domestication small pox is deadly to humans.  Most deadly diseases in humans came from animals we domesticated.  They are harmless to the animal but we have no immunity.  We need to care a  bit less about ourselves and a bit more about colony collapse disorder among honey bees  if honey bees go extinct you will see starvation on a  scale never before seen.

Abdulkarim Elnaas Some frogs and toads can kill  humans if touched.  Its bees collapse that has me worried.  More than global warming a few more storms a little less land we can survive.  But, bees going extinct would kill off most of the biosphere including most humans.

Abdulkarim Elnaas No other bee but European honey bees do the level of pollination  And, its all over thew globe.  While African honey bees seem to fair better they are lazier and harder to control.  One thing that will help is stop trying to make specialized honey like Orange blossom it starves the bees of needed nutrients.

Abdulkarim Elnaas And, its also affecting bees in colder climates to some degree more domestic bees than wild ones   So at least a component is man caused.  Its most likely a multitude of problem.  Including some domestic bees are too much getting only certain plant nectar so not a well balanced diet.    And, domestic bees are being pressed to work even garded.  Climate change could be affecting them though increased storms fluctuation in their natural compass.  And, bees being so important to the environment it is a global crisis.

There are 3 domains: Archaea, Bacteria and Eukaryota  Eukaryota includes 7 groups, each of those groups has 2-3 kingdoms (though I am not sure they are still called like that, current system doesen't really have names for these ranks): Opistokonta, Amoebozoa, Archaeplastida, Excavata, Stramenopiles, Alveolata and Rhizaria.  DON'T use this in your biology class, as this system keeps changing too fast to be implemented in schools and is rather complicated

It's a simple mistake.  No big deal
prokarytoe/eukaryote/archaea

+Raptor Vlogging  The domains are Domain Archaea , Domain Eubacteria, and Domain Eukarya... Archaea and Eubacteria are prokaryotes, it means they don't have cell membrane that covers their nucleus.... and they don't have a complex nucleus..  Eukarya does have a membrane that separates nucleus from other organelles and it has a complex nucleus...     Archaea can handle extreme temperature, acidity, or salinity while most Eubacteria don't.... Archaea has many kingdoms and phyla under it..... but Eubacteria has even more kingdoms and phyla of the bacteria we know or we don't know commonly...... Eukarya has the kingdoms of what we normally see...because Eukarya or the eukaryotes can be unicellular or multi-cellular.... it has the newly set of kingdoms for Protists...(before protists are placed in one kingdom, but now, they are classified even further to have their own kingdoms.... animal-like goes with animal-like....plant-like goes with plant-like....and other bunch of categories as own kingdom)....also the kingdoms of Plantae, Fungi, and Animalia belong in Eukarya.....     and where's Monera?... they made up the two domains of Eubacteria and Archaea.... all bacteria-like organisms either the ones that bring us sickness and diseases or those non-harmful or those which can stand extreme places of high temperature, acidity, and salinity....  Eukarya are eukaryotic.....either multicellular like most of its kingdoms , or unicellular like some kingdoms of protists  Archaea and Eubacteria are all prokaryotic... and therefore all unicellular and smaller than unicellular eukaryotes..   Sorry if my ideas and knowledge were messed up... and just do more research.. it's been a long time since i studied biology...    just want to help. :D

Evolution is real, unlike those :).

Cladistics is a system of classification. Cladistics classifies all things by their evolutionary history, into clades. Evolutionary history is inferred through phylogenetics. So phylogenetic studies are what inform cladistic classification.  There's not much of a difference between a cladogram and a phylogenetic tree. The differences between them are not super well defined like their parent ideas. One way to explore the differences would be to considered almost characterized ideals of two extremes, however real diagrams in real academic journals are in the grey between these two. A cladogram is usually more concerned with relationships than anything else, and usually has little supplemental data. A cladogram will be made to look pretty and/or exemplify relationships at the expense of distorting or ommitting other information. A phylogenetic tree is more concerned with the information that was used to infer relationships. Branch lengths are usually proportional to some trait of interest, and other information such as confidence in support of nodes may be present as well. As a general statement though, a phylogenetic tree is a kind of cladogram, which is why trying to differentiate them seems so tricky.  Speciation is a process in evolution. Evolution is defined as just, "change over time." Biological evolution specifically how life forms, species, change over time, and how new species come into existence. In life it can most simply be said that there is diversity, and complexity. Genetic/genomic are responsible for how a species descendants can be vastly different from ancestors. Geneaological processes (which define speciation), combined with genetic/genomic processes are responsible for why there are separate and distinct populations, different species!  Does that make sense?
